text: Hello, everyone.

I'm excited to
present this research

that I'm doing in
collaboration with a couple

of different graduate student
co-authors including Mackenzie

Preston, who you'll hear from
later today, as part of the PhD
project research collaboration.
This project came out of this.

So as we all know
in summer of 2020

when everyone started
to care about racism,
there was a lot more--

along with that
care about racism

and this heightened societal
attention to racism,

there was also heightened
calls for allyship.

And this can be seen
in the HBR and growth

in a number of articles
that are on the topic,

but also a lot of organizations
are now folding allyship
training into their DEI efforts.

And so as it has
been said and talked

about in this room
earlier today,

allyship is formally defined
as advantaged groups engaging

in committed action to
improve the treatment

and status of
disadvantaged groups,

but whether it's talking
about men as allies for women,

heterosexual individuals as
allies for LGBTQ individuals,

or white people as allies
for racial minorities

and racial justice, there tends
to be this idea that in order

to be an ally, you
have to be a member

of a dominant social
identity group.

So for racial justice,
you have to be white.

And yet we know that a lot of
times the people who are really

crafting programs
to remove inequities

are members of other
marginalized groups.

And so in this case, we're
focused on racial minorities.

So the question is
can a racial minority

be seen as an effective
ally for racial justice.

It has been said multiple
times in the room

today that racial
minorities can be allies,

but what are the
perceptions of them when
they engage in these behaviors?

Existing research
would say, no, they

are not seen as effective
allies or as effective

as a white person because,
in general, racial minorities

are penalized for
engaging in DEI behaviors

and they're seen as
more self-interested.

And yet the majority of
people who are DEI managers

and tasked with-- in their
formal roles-- engaging

in allyship type
behaviors are non-white.

So in this paper centered
on racial minority

leaders in
organizations, we argue

and we take a finer
grain approach
in looking at this allyship.

And we're looking in this
case at same-race allyship
versus cross-race allyship.

So same-race allyship
is a racial minority

who is engaging in behaviors
to remove inequities

for members of their own
group versus another group,

and when you think
of it in this way,

you can see that the same-race
allyship would actually

be the problematic context in
which negative perceptions may
arise.

In particular, we focus on
this negative perception

of in-group favoritism
or you're unfairly

advantaging your
group, and in doing so,

this leads to lower perceptions
of allyship effectiveness

that has downstream consequences
of lower leader effectiveness

and employee's own support
or the racial equity effort.

Most importantly
in this paper, we

identify a moderator
or something

that can be done to reduce
these negative effects.

So I'm going to show you
data from three studies,

and I'm going to get
through it in five minutes.

So in the first study,
we recruited participants

to tell us about times in
their own organizations where

a racial minority
leader has engaged

in either cross-race
or same-race allyship.

We defined it for them
and gave them examples.

They wrote out this
examples, and those examples

were actually
really illuminating.

And we found support for
this first hypothesis

such that same-race
allyship was related

to significantly higher
levels of anger favoritism,

and there was a
significant indirect effect

of that heightened in-group
favoritism to lower perceptions

that this racial minority
leader was indeed
an effective allyship.

In the next study, we presented
participants with vignettes

where leader who was
either Asian or Black

was engaging in either same-race
or cross-race allyship,

and, again, we found these
heightened perceptions

of in-group favoritism when
same-race allyship occurred.

But importantly,
it wasn't different

between the Black leader
or the Asian leader.

So when they were advocating
for their own group,

they were seen as being
higher in in-group favoritism,

and this led to
ultimately lower levels

of leadership effectiveness
and lower participants

saying that they wouldn't really
support this racial equity

effort in the same
way when it was

directed towards another
marginalized racial group.

Lastly, in our final
experiment when

we looked at this
moderated effect,

we looked at allyship framing,
and so with this allyship

framing, we looked at
whether you could highlight

the contributions
of other employees

and their ideas in your allyship
by saying a lot of people

have brought this
to my attention

and I am now raising
this as an idea

that we could do to help
an underrepresented group.

And we found that
this significantly

reduced perceptions of
in-group favoritism,

and the index to the
moderating mediation

all the way through was
significant for both DVs, which

means they also reduced the
negative effects on leader

effectiveness and employee
support for racial equity.
So what does this mean?

It means that a lot of
people in this room today

were right, that
if you are a member

of a marginalized racial group
or a marginalized identity

group, you can be seen
as an effective ally,

and our paper also
provides a pathway forward

for when you are
in positions where

you need to advocate
for your own group

to help those that
are still at lower

levels of an
organizational hierarchy

and reduce the negative
effects of that behavior.
Thank you.
[APPLAUSE]
